title: 110_hr1281
content: The Act titled "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2007" prohibits deceptive practices in federal elections. The Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2007" prohibits deceptive practices in federal elections by imposing fines or imprisonment for knowingly spreading false election-related information to prevent others from voting in federal elections. The term 'election related information' includes details about the time, place, and manner of conducting elections, voter eligibility requirements and restrictions, political party affiliations in closed primary elections, and explicit endorsements by individuals. The new amendment adds restrictions on explicit endorsements of candidates in elections. The amendment increases the penalty for voter intimidation from one year to five years in Federal elections. Additionally, there are modifications to sentencing guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses under title 18 of the United States Code within 90 days of this Act's enactment. The Commission is authorized to make amendments following procedures outlined in the Sentencing Act of 1987. The Attorney General can be informed of violations of specific sections of the United States Code. Upon receiving a report, corrective actions will be taken to provide accurate information to affected voters and refer the matter for legal action if necessary. Regulations regarding this process will be established by the Attorney General. The Attorney General will promulgate regulations for corrective actions in consultation with various organizations. Additionally, a study will be conducted on the feasibility of providing corrective measures. The Attorney General will publicize remedies through various forms of broadcast and media. Additionally, a report detailing the results of a study on corrective information provision will be submitted to Congress. The Attorney General is required to submit a report to Congress within 90 days of any federal election, compiling allegations of false information and deceptive tactics. The report must include detailed information on the allegations, statistical compilations, geographic locations affected, and the status of investigations. The report to Congress must include details on investigations, corrective actions, rationale for actions, effectiveness of actions, Voting Integrity Task Force establishment, referrals to other agencies, lawsuits filed, and criminal prosecutions related to election allegations. The Attorney General must delegate responsibilities to a Voting Integrity Task Force established to address election allegations, with the report being made public online. The Voting Integrity Task Force is established to address election allegations for Federal offices, under the direction of the Assistant Attorney General. Federal office includes President, Vice President, Senators, Representatives, and Delegates. Passed the House of Representatives on June 25, 2007.
